com.fizzikgames.fizlib.util

Class BinaryHeap<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.fizzikgames.fizlib.util.BinaryHeap<T>

  • public class BinaryHeap<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    The binary heap stores a tree of nodes where each node has two children. The heap doesn't keep all of its elements sorted, instead it keeps the top most element as the most desired element. Whether the element is the lowest or highest is determined by the value the object supplies with its implementation of the Comparable interface.
    Version:
    1.02
    Author:
    Maxim Tiourin

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      BinaryHeap()
      Initializes the heap with the default heap size of 20.
      BinaryHeap(int size)
      Define a custom heap size to tailor to your needs, the larger the default size, then the smaller the amount of times the Binary Heap will need to allocate memory whenever elements are being added.

      • BinaryHeap

        public BinaryHeap()
        Initializes the heap with the default heap size of 20.

      • BinaryHeap

        public BinaryHeap(int size)
        Define a custom heap size to tailor to your needs, the larger the default size, then the smaller the amount of times the Binary Heap will need to allocate memory whenever elements are being added.
        Parameters:
        size - size to start the heap at

    • Method Detail

      • add

        public void add(T e)
        Add the element into the heap and sort it. Reallocates if needed.
        Parameters:
        e - element being added

      • update

        public void update(T e)
        Updates the heap starting at the position of the given element. This is useful when elements have their sortValues change and you don't want to clear the heap and add all of the elements to be sorted all over again.
        Parameters:
        e - element to update

      • pop

        public T pop()
        Returns the topmost element of the heap, while also removing it from the heap. Does not reallocate size.
        Returns:
        topmost element

      • remove

        public T remove(T e)
        Removes the element from the heap
        Returns:
        element

      • peek

        public T peek()
        Returns the topmost element of the heap
        Returns:
        topmost element

      • get

        public T get(int index)
        Returns the element with the given index
        Parameters:
        index - of element
        Returns:
        element with given index

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Clears the heap and reallocates

      • allocate

        public void allocate()
        Reallocates the heap if needed. Don't call this unless you have popped a lot of elements off and want to free up some of the empty space. Note that the heap only allocates in increments of the supplied heap size, or the default size of 20.

      • getSize

        public int getSize()
        Returns the amount of elements in the heap
        Returns:
        heap size

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a string representation of the binary heap
        Overrides:

        Returns:
        string representation
